qas.question: How long ago do some paleontologists believe that animals first appeared?
Fossils found in the Tonian period indicate the presence of what creatures?
Triploblastic worms were comparable in size to what other creatures?
When was the beginning of the Tonian period?
What produces tracks similar to the fossilized tracks discovered by paleontologists?

context: Some paleontologists suggest that animals appeared much earlier than the Cambrian explosion, possibly as early as <a0_0>1 billion years<a0_0/> ago. Trace fossils such as tracks and burrows found in the Tonian period indicate the presence of <a1_0>triploblastic worms<a1_0/>, like metazoans, roughly as large (about 5 mm wide) and complex as <a2_0>earthworms<a2_0/>. During the beginning of the Tonian period <a3_0>around 1 billion years ago<a3_0/>, there was a decrease in Stromatolite diversity, which may indicate the appearance of grazing animals, since stromatolite diversity increased when grazing animals went extinct at the End Permian and End Ordovician extinction events, and decreased shortly after the grazer populations recovered. However the discovery that tracks very similar to these early trace fossils are produced today by the giant single-celled protist <a4_0>Gromia sphaerica<a4_0/> casts doubt on their interpretation as evidence of early animal evolution.
